data.title: Tab not quite as expected when using snippets within snippets
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.0.1-insider (1.0.1-insider) - 85f337ee0851a464d5459ce9a354d05f94f0b9a4
- OS Version: OSX Yosemite 10.10.5

See animated gif below (sorry for resolution!):
![animated gif](http://i.giphy.com/xT1XGLJFhjDh4A97zO.gif)

I am not sure if the tab button should continue switching between the outer snippet's placeholders, or if it should respect the inner snippet's placeholders until ESC is pressed, at which point it returns to the outer snippet's context?

data.title: apply file.exclude rules to reference search and go to declaration
data.body: As discusses here #5740, we should consider to honour the exclude settings for files in the reference search window, in go to declaration, and likely other places

data.title: Test previewHtml
data.body:
- [x] mac  @bpasero 
- [x] linux @aeschli
- [x] windows @kieferrm 

Under the hood the previewHtml command use a web view instead of an iframe. Test that
- existing extensions like preview svg, preview css etc still work
- a web view cannot ruin the outer VS Code process, with an `while(true);` for instance
- a web view can run scripts
- check items from the [previous assignment](#2099)

data.title: Test virtual document links
data.body:
- [x] any os @bpasero 
- [x] any os @kieferrm 
#3676, make sure links in virtual document. Test that:
- you link to a document on disk, e.g `file:///Users/far/b.oo`
- you link to a virtual document, e.g. `virtual:some/path`
- you can jump to a line using the `#L32` notion, `file:///Users/far/b.oo#L42`
- you can invoke a command using using the command scheme and the command as path, like so `command:deleteLeft`
- you can invoke a command with arguments by adding a JSON-array of them as query

data.title: Default font on Ubuntu looks terrible (should we ship a font with vscode?)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 

Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) no longer carries `Droid Sans Mono`, this causes font to be rendered with `Courier New` if Linux desktop user installed MS core fonts (more than likely). Given Ubuntu still carries open source fonts such as `DejaVu Sans Mono` or `Liberation Mono`, which are better for LCD than `Courier New`, consider: 
- Adding those to the font list
- Remove `Courier New` from font list - let the OS decide

Steps to Reproduce:
1. KEIL Uvision 3 software creates text file that contains functions code and it's assembler codes. when I want to go to definition it opens peek definition window and shows me 2 definitions: one is that txt file with code and assembler code and second is real function. What is interesting, that I added OBJ folder to exclude files and i cant see this file in my file tree. And it is not only with functions but also with defines.

data.title: Compare not working for large XML files?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise SP1 64 bits
- .Net Framework 4.5.2 installed

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download the two following sample XML files:
   https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B0GuFolRSbJ-aHhhLW5RRDU4eUU
   https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B0GuFolRSbJ-bDB0eFVZMTE4bkk
2. Choose "Select for Compare" on first file in Explorer bar
3. Choose "Compare with" on the second file

No highlight of differences. VSCode works fine with smaller files. Both files are UTF-8 encoded.

data.title: Debug: repl shows up everytime when I press F5
data.body:
I thought we would be smarter here and only bring up the repl on the first debug launch but not subsequent launches when the user has closed the repl. I thought we would use the viewlet icon decoration to indicate that there is new output.

@isidorn maybe a regression?

data.title: Webview: allow me to adjust my content based on theme
data.body:
I am providing content to the webview via my extension. The user can switch between dark and light theme so I would like my content to adjust based on the selected theme.

I think the simplest solution would be to just set a CSS class on the container I am hosted in that reflects the theme that is being used (light or dark). 

Another thought I had was to maybe leverage CSS variables that are available in recent Chrome releases (https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2016/02/css-variables-why-should-you-care?hl=en). I could get access to the base colors a theme defines via variables.

In the end, maybe both things are desired.

@jrieken fyi

data.title: Webview does not work in built version of VS Code
data.body: Because vs/workbench/parts/html/browser/webview.html is missing from the build.

data.title: We need a API - positionAt(byte offset)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: windows 10

I want to make the extension ["clang-format"](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=xaver.clang-format) work better with chinese(or other asia languages).But clang-format only provide byte offsets of a text.Using [TextDocument.positionAt](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#TextDocument.positionAt), we will got a Position object with charactor offset but not byte offset.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run "clang-format -output-replacements-xml -style=llvm" for file https://github.com/atframework/atframe_utils/blob/master/include/string/ac_automation.h, we get the first replacement node with offset='288' and length='180'.
2. We use [TextDocument.positionAt](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#TextDocument.positionAt)(288), we get line=19 and col=15
3. But what we want is line=19 and col=1
4. The problem is "自动机算法实现"(UTF-8) takes 21 bytes, but VSCode think it has 7 charaters.

I think it's better for vscode provide a API to do so, than we analysis all the content again.

From http://stackoverflow.com/a/33956083/1156119

``` json
"git.enabled": false,
```

I tried it and was expecting the icon to be hidden. It's also unclear whether `git.autofetch` does anything if `git.enabled` is set to `false`.

data.title: Debugging with babel-register + NodeJs does not work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.3

Setup Steps:
1. Download and expand [NodeJsWithBabelDebuggingExample.ZIP](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/233815/NodeJsWithBabelDebuggingExample.ZIP)
   into a local folder.
2. Open the Terminal and point it to the folder from Step 1.
3. Run `npm install` (to install the Babel dependencies).
4. Run `npm start` (to demonstrate that the project is working Node program) which should produce a few lines of output and no errors.

Steps to Reproduce (on Mac OS):
1. In VS Code, open the folder created in the steps above.
2. Press F5 to start debugging the program.
3. Observe the debugger break at line 1 of ./index.js, which is a comment.  (This is the first sign of trouble.)
4. Repeatedly press F10 (to step) and observe the debugger break on various other lines of ./index.js that have nothing to do with the code being executed.

Apparently, the inline source map generated by Babel is either being missed, ignored, or misinterpreted.  It is also possible that the source map may be faulty, but seeing as a similar setup using other tools (such as Chrome Dev Tools) results in accurate debugging (and only when the source map is supplied) suggests that this is not the case.

Btw, VS Code gives zero feedback (as far as I can see) as to whether a source map was found and/or is being used, making it almost impossible to diagnose this type of trouble.

A few questions:
1. Have a done something wrong in this setup?  Is there something wrong or missing in my launch.json or package.json (where the Babel settings are)?
2. Are there some diagnostics that I can enable in VS Code to help determine what is going wrong?
3. Should I even expect to be able to successfully perform source-level debugging of dynamically-transpiled code with VS Code like this, or not?  (Other tools can do it, so I will be disappointed if this is not a supported use-case for VS Code.)

The VS Code web pages (https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/debugging) certainly make this sound like I should reasonably expect debugging to work:

> Source maps can be generated with two kinds of inlining:
> - Inlined source maps: the generated JavaScript file contains the source map as a data URI at the end (instead of referencing the source map through a file URI).
> - Inlined source: the source map contains the original source (instead of referencing the source through a path).
> 
> VS Code supports both the inlined source maps and the inlined source.

As far as I know, setting `{ "sourceMaps": "inline" }` in the Babel configuration (which this project does via package.json) adheres to the first case ("inlined source maps") which the above quote from the VS Code web pages seems to suggest is supported.

Thanks.

data.title: Find and replace ctrl+enter only works when focus is in replace text box
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>h</kbd>
2. Focus find
3. Type "a", or something with matches in the file
4. <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>enter</kbd> **does not replace all**
5. Focus replace
6. <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>enter</kbd> **replaces all**

Mousing over the replace all button shows the keybinding <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>enter</kbd>, not <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>enter</kbd>. It also doesn't seem to have an entry in keybindings.json so I'm a little confused whether it's a bug that it works at all.

data.title: Fix a typo in Contributing.md prose
After closing a scope, another stopped event should not open it again
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha

If I close a scope (because it has too many variables and slows down stepping), another 'stopped' event  should not open it again automatically.

This would help alleviate the problem with stepping through code with thousands of variables.

data.title: VS Code does not honour the 'expensive' flag for all scopes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha

If node debug returns an `expensive` flag with value `true` for all scopes, VS Code still expands the 'local' scope (or the first 'scope').
